After all, many of our basic contemporary principleshuman rights, toleration, even the religious-secular distinctionhave roots in Christian theology and canon law that predate Hobbess Leviathan. And, on the other hand, not every aspect of political life in Christendom was shaped by biblical revelation; customary law and raw calculation also played major roles. In other words, can one really pinpoint a moment in Western political history when the Great Separation took place?

If one is looking for a precise moment when Western institutions and customs were suddenly (miraculously?) transformed, the answer is no. Political history does not work that way. But The Stillborn God is not a narrative political history; it is an episodic history of ideas that reconstructs an argument that coursed through several centuries of Western thought. And in that argument there was indeed a clean break: the publication of Hobbess Leviathan. Hobbes truly changed the subject, demonstrating that it was possible to establish the legitimacy of a states authority over its citizens without making any appeal to a divinely revealed nexus of God, man, and world. He showed how to replace political theology with a humanistic political anthropology, and though traditional political theology continued to be written in the West (and still is), it now had to contend with this fresh alternative.

By what means Hobbess intellectual revolution eventually shaped Western political history is a vast subject not broached in The Stillborn God. Its focus is on the intellectual chess moves, so to speak, that were developed in response to Hobbess ideas. The principles of our contemporary liberal democracies depend crucially on his critique of political theology, even if they were also inspired (and softened) by biblical ideas of human dignity and autonomy. Those latter ideas have indeed been secularized over the past several centuries. But the idea that man could rule himself legitimately, without any reference to revealed divine authority, required a Great (intellectual) Separation.

AN AMERICAN EXCEPTION?

FOR BOTH critics and defenders of religions role in contemporary political life, the American example refutes all facile claims about the progressive secularization of modern society. But does it also challenge the legacy of the Great Separation? It must be admitted that the American experience is exceptional: there is no other fully developed industrial society with a population so committed to its faiths (and such exotic ones), while being equally committed to the principles of liberal democracy. American political rhetoric, which owes much to the Protestant sectarians of the seventeenth century, vibrates with messianic energy, and Americans still have potentially explosive religious differences over abortion, prayer in schools, censorship, euthanasia, biological research, and other matters. And in recent decades the religious Right has become highly organized and makes its weight felt in electoral politics and legal discourse. For religions critics, this shows that church-state separation, and thus the U.S. Constitution, is under threat; for religions defenders, it is further proof that the United States was founded on biblical values, which deserve public recognition and defense.

Both groups have a point, yet seem to miss the larger point. Retrospectively, we can now see that the achievement of the Great Separationwhatever the intention of its partisans at different timeswas neither to banish religion entirely from public life, nor to secure it an environment in which it could flourish. The real accomplishment was to decouple basic questions of legitimate public authority, which are left entirely in human hands, from religions fate more broadly in society. Granted, in the American case it was aided in this by Protestant traditions of dissent that opened up theological space for thinking about the autonomy of politics; and, on the other hand, the American system provided space for religious prophets of various political causesfor and against slavery, for and against womens suffrage, for and against civil rights, for and against abortionto call their fellow citizens to judgment. But by and large, Americans accept the principle, derived from Hobbess attack on political theology, that it is the consent of We, the People that alone renders the Constitution legitimate. And if they happen also to believe, against Hobbes, that they are endowed by their Creator with certain unalienable Rights, they take that truth to be self-evident, not divinely revealed. American politics makes astonishing room for prophets to market their waresso long as they retire to their churches once the ballots are cast. And they generally do.

Which is not to say that political theology poses no potential challenge to the Great Separation in the United States today. One lesson of The Stillborn God is that we should never be complacent about its potential to ignite messianic passions. Rousseau was on to something: we seem to be theotropic creatures, yearning to connect our mundane lives, in some way, to the beyond. That urge can be suppressed, new habits learned, but the allure of political theology will never fully disappear so long as the urge to connect survives. That is why public vigilance and civic education remain crucial, even in Americas stable liberal democracy. The fact that many Americans have exaggerated worries about religions role in contemporary politics is probably not a bad thing.

A CLASH OF CIVILIZATIONS?

2006

OF COURSE, the most evident threat from political theology is apparent in the Muslim world today, where a classic form of revolutionary messianism has made an equally classic challenge to the principles of the Great Separation. We were reminded of this in 2006 when Iranian President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad wrote an open letter to American President George Bush, in which he claimed that liberalism and Western style democracy have not been able to help realize the ideals of humanity. Today these two concepts have failed. Those with insight can already hear the sounds of the shattering and fall of the ideology and thoughts of the liberal democratic systems. Whether we like it or not, the world is gravitating towards faith in the Almighty and justice and the will of God will prevail over all things.

What kind of light does The Stillborn God shed on this phenomenon? My hope is that it reminds us that political theology is not the preserve of any one culture or religion, nor does it belong solely to the past. It is an age-old habit of mind that can be reacquired by anyone who begins looking to the divine nexus of God, man, and world to reveal the legitimate political order. It also reminds us how political theology can be adapted to circumstances and reassert itself, even in the face of seemingly irresistible forces like modernization, secularization, and democratization. There is no triumphalist lesson to be found in this book, nor does it prophesy a clash of civilizations. It is, quite simply, a plea for modesty and humility. (This is even true in relation to the Wests own past: let us remember that the most appalling political crimes of recent memory have had nothing to do with political theology.)

But if we grant that political theology is a perennial option in human thought about legitimate rule, does it follow that the Great Separation is also a live alternative to the strongest political theology of our time, radical Islamism? Here I must register my doubts. For all the good Hobbes did in shifting our political focus from God to man, he left the impression that the challenge of political theology would vanish once the cycle of fear was broken and human beings established authority over their own affairs. We still make this assumption when speaking of the social causes of fundamentalism and political messianism, as if the amelioration of material conditions or the shifting of borders would automatically trigger a Great Separation. Nothing in our history or contemporary experience confirms this belief: when the urge to connect is strong, passions are high, and fantasies are vivid, the trinkets of our modern lives are impotent amulets against political intoxication. And so we find ourselves in an intellectual bind when we encounter radical Islamism today. Either we assume that modernization and secularization will eventually extinguish it, or we treat it as an incomprehensible, existential threat, using familiar terms like fascism to describe it as best we can. Neither response takes us a step closer to understanding the world we now live in.

It is a world in which millions of Muslims believe that God has revealed a law governing the whole of human affairs. Like Orthodox Jewish law (halakha), the Muslim sharia is meant to cover the whole of life, not some arbitrarily demarcated private sphere, and its legal system has few traditional resources for establishing the independence of politics from detailed divine commands. As The Stillborn God demonstrates, the political crisis that helped Hobbes promote his Great Separation was a crisis within Christendom, with roots deep in the theological ambiguities of Christian revelation. It was precisely the absence of a comprehensive divine law recognized by all Christians that kept alive the medieval contest over political authority, eventually provoking the search for an alternative to all political theology. Since neither Jewish halakha nor Muslim sharia give rise to this problem, neither has generated the search for a similar alternative. Rather, in the nineteenth century, many Westernized Muslim thinkers explored the same liberal theological options that European Protestants and Jews did, with equally feeble results.

Is there no other alternative to the most powerful messianic political theology of our time? I think there may be, in a renewal of moderate political theology from within orthodox Islam. As we saw in the story of Protestant and Jewish liberal theology, liberal reformers are apologists for religion at the court of modern life, hoping to adapt the former to the alien demands of the latter. Theological renovators, on the other hand, stand firmly within their faiths and reinterpret political theology so believers can adapt without feeling themselves to be apostates. Luther and Calvin were theological renovators in this sense, not liberal reformers. They called Christians back to the fundamentals of their faith, but in a way that eventually made it easier, not harder, for them to enjoy the fruits of temporal existence. And they did this, not by speaking the apologetic language of toleration and progress, but by rewriting the language of Christian political theology and demanding that Christians be faithful to it.

If we cannot expect a sudden embrace of the Great Separation in the Muslim worldand we cannotwe had better learn to welcome moderate transformations in Islamic political theology that might improve political life. We have little reason to expect societies in the grip of a powerful tradition of political theology to follow our unusual path, which was opened up by a unique crisis within Christian civilization. This does not mean that those societies necessarily lack the wherewithal to create a decent and workable political order; it does mean that they will have to find the theological resources within their own traditions to make it happen. And that will be up them, not us.





20083

New York City,

March 2008

Acknowledgments

2003

THIS BOOK is based on my Carlyle Lectures, delivered at Oxford University in Hilary Term 2003. I wish to express my gratitude to the university and to the Carlyle committee for the invitation. My research on this subject has been supported over the past decade by a number of organizations in the United States and Germany, and they also deserve my thanks: the Guggenheim Foundation, the Institute for Advanced Study, the Alexander von Humboldt Foundation, the Einstein Forum, and the Earhart Foundation.

11. (Immanuel Kant)Bemerkungen zu den Beobachtungen ber das Gefhl des Schnen und ErhabenenKants gesammelte Schriften (1908)XX:44Akademie Edition Ak.

11. Immanuel Kant, Bemerkungen zu den Beobachtungen ber das Gefhl des Schnen und Erhabenen, Kants gesammelte Schriften (Berlin, 1908), XX:44. Whenever possible, page references below refer to the standard volume number and pagination of this German Akademie Edition (hereafter Ak.), which are reproduced in most English translations.

12. B 29495A1781B17871929

12. Immanuel Kant, Kritik der reinen Vernunft (hereafter Critique of Pure Reason), B 29495. It is conventional in all German and translated editions of this work to refer to the pagination of the first edition of 1781 with an A and of the revised second edition of 1787 with a B, and not to refer to the Akademie pagination. In English: Critique of Pure Reason, trans. Norman Kemp Smith (London, 1929).

19. Immanuel Kant, Vorlesungen ber die philosophische Religionslehre, XXVIII:1072. In English: Lectures on the Philosophical Doctrine of Religion, in Cambridge Religion and Rational Theology. At several junctures in his work Kant makes the claim that we must postulate God, not always in the same way. Among the passages to consider are: Critique of Pure Reason, B 83941; Critique of Practical Reason, V:5, 14546; Kritik der Urteilskraft, V:45153 (in English: Critique of Judgment, trans. Werner S. 4. The Bourgeois God

1. 1943-1985299 1988155-156

1. The provenance of the text remains uncertain. Though written in Hegels hand, the scholarly consensus now attributes it to his friend, the poet Hlderlin. The quotation here is taken from Friedrich Hlderlin, Smtliche Werke (Stuttgart, 194385), IV:299. A rough translation, which I have altered, can be found in Friedrich Hlderlin, Essays and Letters on Theory, trans. Thomas Pfau (Albany, N.Y., 1988), 15556.

2. GWF HegelDer Geist der Christentums und sein SchicksalHegels theologische Jugendschriften ed1907 332 TM 1948 289

3. 633635 31214

4. GWF Eva Moldenhauer Karl Markus Michel 1970 8 23-25 11-12 1-244 GWF TF Geraets 1991 377-577 William Wallace 1971 G.W.F. 1993-95184-185182418271831C. 1984-8788573

4. G.W.F. Hegel, Enzyklopdie der philosophischen Wissenschaften im Grundrisse (hereafter Encyclopedia), preface to 2nd ed., in Werke, ed. Eva Moldenhauer and Karl Markus Michel, (Frankfurt, 1970), 8:2325 (1112). Unless otherwise noted, all references to Hegels works are to this edition, followed in parentheses by pages in the corresponding English translation when necessary. The prefaces and 1244 are found in G.W.F. Hegel, The Encyclopedia Logic, trans. T. F. Geraets et al. (Indianapolis, 1991); 377577 are found in Hegels Philosophy of Mind, trans. William Wallace (Oxford, 1971). The second quoted phrase is from G.W.F. Hegel, Vorlesungen ber die Philosophie der Religion (hereafter Philosophy of Religion), ed. Walter Jaeschke, 3 vols. (Hamburg, 199395), 3:18485. This edition brings together material from Hegels lectures of 1824, 1827, and 1831. I have used the translation edited by Peter C. Hodgson, Lectures on the Philosophy of Religion, 3 vols. (Berkeley: University of California Press, 198487), which intercollates the pages of the Jaeschke edition. One should also compare Philosophy of Religion, 1:88, to Encyclopedia, 573.

Sibrees translation, The Philosophy of History (New York, 1899). Compare these passages to G. Hegel, Philosophy of Religion 1:34547.

Mark Lilla



THE STILLBORN GOD

         

         

GB

Mark Lilla is Professor of the Humanities at Columbia University. A noted intellectual historian and frequent contributor to The New York Review of Books, he is the author of The Reckless Mind: Intellectuals in Politics and G. B. Vico: The Making of an Anti-Modern. He lives in New York City.

         

         



www.knopfspeakersbureau.com 212-572-2013

Mark Lilla is available for lectures and readings.

For information regarding his availability, please visit www.knopfspeakersbureau.com or call 212-572-2013.

ALSO BY MARK LILLA

The Reckless Mind: Intellectuals in Politics

GB Vico

G. B. Vico: The Making of an Anti-Modern

New French Thought: Political Philosophy (editor)

The Legacy of Isaiah Berlin (coeditor)





Praise for Mark Lillas



THE STILLBORN GOD

One of those rare books that repays careful reading. It has much to teach about where we of the West are today, and the strange journey by which we have arrived here.

The American Interest

Elegant. Lilla writes not only learnedly, but beautifully.

Haaretz

Will be enjoyed by anyone who appreciates a historic explanation of this particularly important way we have come to regard both religion and politics.

The Commercial Dispatch

Masterful. Lilla is a marvelously concise and lucidwriter.

-

Salon

Marked by impressive learning, as well as by a gift for translating some of the more stylistically challenged philosophers (Hobbes, Kant, Hegel) into language accessible to the nonspecialist.

Commentary magazine

A cautionary tale for all who would seek to reintroduce religion into politics.

Lexington Herald-Ledger

FOOTNOTES

*11920

*1 Readers will note the absence of modern Catholic thinkers from this study. The reason is that the argument reconstructed here largely bypassed Catholic theologians until the early twentieth century, owing to the institutional isolation of Catholic higher education and the Churchs hostile attitude toward modern society throughout most of the nineteenth century. Telling the Catholic story would require a separate book.

Return to text.

*2

*2 Strictly speaking, there is a distinction between pantheism, which equates God with the cosmos, and panentheism, which sees the cosmos as contained within God, who remains greater than it. For our purposes, we can consider both doctrines as pantheistic.

Return to text.

*3270

*3 It would, however, be anachronistic to label Hegel a promoter of religious tolerance as we understand it today. In the Philosophy of Right (270) he asserts that, since religion is what integrates individuals into the state, citizens should be required to belong to some sort of religious community, and the state should ensure that the churches are protected and financially supported. But not just any religion is to receive state encouragement. In a long footnote he addresses those groupsQuakers, Anabaptists, Jewswhose faith, he believes, may make it impossible for them fully to take part in the political life of the state. Such people should be tolerated in the realm of civil society, but only if the state is strong, which means that the religions must be relatively weak. Individuals in such groups can be granted civil rights as human beings, even if, as in the case of the Jews, they could be plausibly thought to belong to a foreign Volk. In short, while toleration is possible in Hegels scheme, membership only in certain Protestant churches appears to be fully consistent with citizenship in the modern state as he conceives it.

Return to text.

*418421851

*4 It was, however, attempted. The first to try was Samuel Hirsch, a German Jewish rabbi who later became a leader of the Reform movement in American Judaism. In an early work, The Religious Philosophy of the Jews (1842), Hirsch claimed to show that Judaism, properly understood, is perfectly identical with Hegels absolute knowing and therefore stands at the culmination of history. Another attempt was made by Nachman Krochmal, whose slightly wild work, Guide for the Perplexed of Our Time (1851), tried to refute Hegels dismissal of Judaism as a static state religion by redescribing Jewish history as a series of cycles rising in a progressive cycle, which was now culminating in an enlightened, reformed faith fully compatible with Hegels conception of the modern state.

Return to text.

Vintage Books 2008 9
